metadata.name: PowerShell Script Dropped Via PowerShell.EXE
metadata.comment: Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM file_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND (endswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('\\powershell.exe')) OR endswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('\\pwsh.exe'))) AND endswith(lower(file.path), lower('.ps1')) AND NOT (contains(lower(file.path), lower('__psscriptpolicytest_')) OR startswith(lower(file.path), lower('c:\\users\\')) AND contains(lower(file.path), lower('\\appdata\\local\\temp\\')) OR startswith(lower(file.path), lower('c:\\windows\\temp\\'))))

output.summary: Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

metadata.objective: False positive: False positives will differ depending on the environment and scripts used. Apply additional filters accordingly. Reference: https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/onenote-growing-threat-malware-distribution
